clues.text: Jonathan Swift inspired a title, writing you can know a true genius by the sign that these are "in confederacy against him"
A.W. Wheen, a WWI vet like the author, chose this English title in translating a book whose German title means "nothing new in the west"
The opening line of William Butler Yeats' "Sailing to Byzantium" provided the title for this Cormac McCarthy novel
This original English title of Proust's 7-volume work is from Shakespeare's Sonnet 30
The poetic line "Bury my heart at" this place used it as an evocative American name; as a book, it's about the Native Amer. plight
A fleet of 200 warships of this republic won a battle off Sicily in 241 B.C., leading to the end of the First Punic War
The sinking of the cruiser General Belgrano accounted for almost half of Argentine fatalities in this conflict
During the Civil War Battle of Mobile Bay, David Farragut famously yelled, "Damn" these weapons! "Full speed ahead!"
Gaining even more fame in the next World War, he built up the royal navy for WWI as First Lord of the Admiralty
After the 1905 mutiny on the Russian Battleship Potemkin, its sailors set course for this port city on the Black Sea
The Bible calls her "the mother of all living"
The Bible book named for her says she was also known as Hadassah
The mother of Samuel, her 6-letter name is a palindrome
Shadrach, Meshach & Abednego endured a stay in a furnace in the book of this man
Head to the end of the alphabet for this name of Moses' wife
Stress on the second syllable of this word means to decline an offer; if the stress is on the first, it means trash
Often paired with flotsam, it's thrown off a ship to aid stability during a crisis
Solid particles at the bottom of a cup of coffee are called "the" this 5-letter plural word
This "itus" isn't a medical condition; it's debris often of organic matter like fallen leaves
In England it refers to any of the entrails of an animal, like brawn or chitterlings
"There's a fire starting in my heart, reaching a fever pitch it's bringing me out the dark"
"On a dark desert highway, cool wind in my hair, warm smell of Colitas rising up through the air"
"Well, it's one for the money, 2 for the show, 3 to get ready, now go cat go"
"Almost heaven, West Virginia, Blue Ridge Mountains, Shenandoah River"
"I've never seen a diamond in the flesh, I cut my teeth on wedding rings in the movies"
Mindy Pelz has books called "Eat Like a Girl" & its opposite, do this (maybe intermittently) "Like a Girl"
"The Memoir, Part One" is the subtitle of a recent book by this pop culture icon & singer of "Gypsies, Tramps & Thieves"
About a decade ago this late Nobel Prize winner reflected on his experiences from age 90 in "A Full Life"
One mom in "The Anxious Generation", about the damage tech does, gave her daughter this kind of "phone & she returned" to normal
The idea of a double self informs this memoir by Naomi Klein, a "Trip into the Mirror World" of being confused with Naomi Wolf

rounds.category: YOU PUT ME ON THE SUPREME COURT

clues.text: Making Ketanji Brown Jackson the first Black woman on the court
Breaking new ground (at last) with Sandra Day O'Connor
Hot dogging it & appointing Felix Frankfurter; he wanted to add 6 more all at once, but it didn't happen
Replacing Thurgood Marshall with Clarence Thomas
Choosing who would be a future Chief Justice in William Rehnquist
In 1817 this British physician first described what came to be known as his disease in his "Essay on the Shaking Palsy"
It's the singular last name of Thomas, a doctor whose name is on the malignant disease of lymph tissue he described in 1832
Those most prone to develop this gastrointestinal disease are people in their 20s, not old witchy women
At a hospital in Norway in 1873, this doctor discovered the leprosy bacillus in a patient's tissue sample
Named for Robert from Dublin, this disease causes hyperthyroidism & patients can experience vision loss
Not the Amazon but the more than 1,900-mile-long São Francisco is the longest river entirely within this country
Dawson City, population 30,000 in the late 1890s, population 1,500 today, sits at the confluence of these 2 rivers
Australia's longest river, it bears the name of a Scottish soldier & British Colonial secretary
This name of a great river means "son of" a Hindu creator god
"Y", yes, this giant river of Central Asia flows through Kyzyl, Russia & empties into the Arctic Ocean
I'll admit, reading about creepy, orphaned twin boys in "Red Rain" by this author gave me goosebumps
This No. 1 nonfiction bestseller detailed lives lost aboard a doomed fishing vessel in 1991
Now making a big move on the outside is the beloved horse "Misty of" this Virginia resort island
In 2016 George R.R. Martin blew in with an excerpt from this very anticipated but unpublished novel (sorry, folks, it'll come when it comes)
We learn "That Smilla is a damn great lady... one hundred percent" in this Peter Høeg novel

Finished &
vie

Poetry &
a Gaelic language

A bit of color &
Pulitzer-winning playwright William

A goat &
a marketplace

To intimidate &
a certain female family member
To a firefighter, "the stick" is this, extending 100 feet or more upward from a truck
A restaurant "cover" is one guest; this follows a number to indicate how many guests a table seats, as in a "4-" or "6-" this
The pilots on an airline flight are the cockpit crew; the flight attendants are part of this other crew
To a London cabbie, a long shift is a this, the composer of "Night And Day"
If you work in the rag trade, you're familiar with this hyphenated French equivalent of "ready-to-wear"

rounds.text: With a metro area of more than 9 million, this port city founded in 1576 is the world's most populous Portuguese-speaking capital
